Government benefits watchdog to examine 'callous' shake-up denying disability payments to 150,000 people The official body is due to meet a week after MPs voiced their fury in a heated Commons debate at changes to Personal Independence Payment (PIP) Share Comments By Dan Bloom 18:13, 28 FEB 2017 Updated 18:18, 28 FEB 2017 News Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch Next Suspected burglars spot CCTV too late during £50, Watch this video again Watch Next MPs are victorious at the annual Pancake Day race 1:53 Fancy dress Jesus gets his cross stuck on undergr 0:21 The new Nissan concept with a dog pampering kit b 1:57 How would Donald Trump grade current performance 0:45 Scientists at Queen Mary University have trained 0:33 Dad downs bottle of tequila for bet - then dies m 0:33 Video will play in Watch: Damian Green and Debbie Abrahams go head to head Share this video Watch Next The Tory government's benefits watchdog is set to examine a "callous" new law denying 150,000 people increased disability payments.
The official body will meet next week after MPs voiced their fury today at changes to Personal Independence Payment (PIP).
Ministers drew up emergency laws to block two tribunals which said PIP, which funds disabled people's living costs, should be widened to more people at a cost of £3.7bn.
They controversially did not consult the government's Social Security Advisory Committee (SSAC) - a panel of more than a dozen experts and charity chiefs who look at welfare policy.
Read More Jeremy Corbyn signs bid to kill off law denying increased disability benefits to 150,000 people But today Work and Pensions Secretary Damian Green said the SSAC "still have the power to look at these regulations and make recommendations".
The committee's next monthly meeting is next Wednesday and it is understood the PIP row is almost certain to be raised.
The Social Security Advisory Committee routinely examines benefit changes (Photo: REX/Shutterstock) The SSAC has the power to demand a written response from the Tory minister and recommend he changes specific points in the policy.
Confirmation came after angry exchanges in the House of Commons that saw MPs condemn the "callous" and "distressing" shake-up.
Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Debbie Abrahams said: "Disabled people are twice as likely to live in poverty. How many disabled people will be driven into debt or face poverty as a result of these cuts?
"What is the cumulative effect of these cuts along with [ESA disability benefit] cuts that are due to come into effect in April, which will affect 500,000 disabled people?"
Tory minister Mr Green shot back: "It is simply not a cut. It is not entirely honest of her to say that it is a cut."
But he was rapped by Commons Speaker John Bercow, who said: "There can be no accusation of dishonesty in this chamber."
Debbie Abrahams demanded: "How many disabled people will be driven into debt?" Later Mr Green claimed "the idea this was slipped out is simply ridiculous" - despite the fact the laws were published on the day of two by-elections.
And he claimed it was "simply wrong to say this will deny people PIP" - despite his own equality analysis saying 165,000 people would have got higher payments.
Labour's Rachel Reeves accused him of "overruling the courts and depriving these people of the support they desperately need."
SNP MP Corri Wilson said the mentally ill were worst-hit, adding: "We cannot and should not pit one disability against another."
Labour MP David Winnick said: "The strong feeling among so many of the vulnerable that they will again be in the firing line."
Labour MP Angela Eagle added: "Long-term disabled people are being denied [PIP] and being caused massive amounts of distress by the process. They feel utter despair at having to have anything to do with it."
Even Tory MP Peter Bone - who heaped praise on the "caring" minister - said: "I am fed up with seeing every week a constituent who clearly should have been awarded PIP but is not getting it."
Damian Green faced angry questions in the House of Commons (Photo: REUTERS) The tribunals that are being blocked said people who suffer "overwhelming psychological distress" when they leave home should score higher in PIP assessments than they do now.
That includes people with autism, dementia, schizophrenia, post-traumatic stress and depression.
Labour MP Jim Fitzpatrick read a letter from a PTSD and anxiety sufferer condemning George Freeman - the No10 policy chief who said benefits should only go to the "really disabled".
The letter said: "I am deeply distressed and angry about his remarks. Considering the current lack of funding and social stigma that mentally disabled people already have to suffer, this is beyond the pale."
At least 28 MPs including Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn have signed a Lib Dem motion to kill off the PIP changes completely.
They took effect on February 23, but can be annulled if the House of Commons votes against the motion within 40 days and nights.
There is no guaranteed vote and the last time a similar law was defeated in the same way was 1979.
Mr Green said he had spoken to the SSAC's chairman before announcing the law and ministers will meet the mental health charity Mind.
He added: "This is not a policy change or a cut. Nobody will receive less benefit than they were originally awarded by the DWP."
